question.title: Is there any way to create a primitive array without initialization?

node.contents: Good point. If there were a confirmation of it I would say that the case is closed.

astNode.text: Good point. If there were a confirmation of it I would say that the case is closed.

node.contents: Just create a large array and fill it with 0s using `java.util.Arrays.fill(char[] a, char val)`, measuring the time, to find out that the initialization time is negligible compared with the time required to fill the array with meaningful data.

astNode.text: Just create a large array and fill it with 0s using `java.util.Arrays.fill(char[] a, char val)`, measuring the time, to find out that the initialization time is negligible compared with the time required to fill the array with meaningful data.

node.contents: No, you can't avoid it. That's how it works.

astNode.text: No, you can't avoid it. That's how it works.

node.contents: I'm not sure I understand. All primitives have a default value. What are you trying to accomplish?

astNode.text: I'm not sure I understand. All primitives have a default value. What are you trying to accomplish?

node.contents: What would you have Java put in the place of the 0? You can't just not initialise certain parts of an array.

astNode.text: What would you have Java put in the place of the 0? You can't just not initialise certain parts of an array.

node.contents: About the question how much time it takes it will of course vary widely depending on platform. It should be very easy for you to test though.

astNode.text: About the question how much time it takes it will of course vary widely depending on platform. It should be very easy for you to test though.

node.contents: He's basically wanting it to work like C where you basically have garbage (whatever happens to be in that memory) until you initialize it yourself. Java explicitly avoids this by initializing the memory when you allocate the array because an array is actually an object not just some contiguous memory.

astNode.text: He's basically wanting it to work like C where you basically have garbage (whatever happens to be in that memory) until you initialize it yourself. Java explicitly avoids this by initializing the memory when you allocate the array because an array is actually an object not just some contiguous memory.

node.contents: i mean that e.g. new int[1000000] consists of 2 operations. first - memory allocation, second - JVM goes over the array and sets all elements to 0. But ususally we create an array then copy some data to it or use it in InputStream.read(byte[]). In both cases who cares what the initial values were?

astNode.text: i mean that e.g. new int[1000000] consists of 2 operations. first - memory allocation, second - JVM goes over the array and sets all elements to 0. But ususally we create an array then copy some data to it or use it in InputStream.read(byte[]). In both cases who cares what the initial values were?

node.contents: @EvgeniyDorofeev - no, it doesn't. An array in Java is an object on the heap rather than just a pointer to some memory on the stack/heap. It's .... just not the same thing.

astNode.text: @EvgeniyDorofeev - no, it doesn't. An array in Java is an object on the heap rather than just a pointer to some memory on the stack/heap. It's .... just not the same thing.

node.contents: Also, I wouldn't be shocked if the JVM were smart enough to notice you were immediately writing over the array contents and omit the initialization.

astNode.text: Also, I wouldn't be shocked if the JVM were smart enough to notice you were immediately writing over the array contents and omit the initialization.

node.contents: As we know Java always initialises arrays upon creation. I.e. new int[1000000] always returns an array with all elements = 0. I understand that it's a must for Object arrays, but for primitive arrays (except may be Boolean) in most cases we don't care about the initial values.

astNode.text: As we know Java always initialises arrays upon creation. I.e. new int[1000000] always returns an array with all elements = 0. I understand that it's a must for Object arrays, but for primitive arrays (except may be Boolean) in most cases we don't care about the initial values.

node.contents: Does anybody know a way to avoid this intialization?

astNode.text: Does anybody know a way to avoid this intialization?

node.contents: I'm going to move this to an answer because it probably should be.

astNode.text: I'm going to move this to an answer because it probably should be.

node.contents: An "Array" in java is not what you think it is. It's not just a pointer to a chunk of contiguous memory on the stack or heap.

astNode.text: An "Array" in java is not what you think it is. It's not just a pointer to a chunk of contiguous memory on the stack or heap.

node.contents: An Array in Java is an Object just like everything else (except primitives) and is on the heap. When you call new int[100000] you're creating a new object just like every other object, and it gets initialized, etc.

astNode.text: An Array in Java is an Object just like everything else (except primitives) and is on the heap. When you call new int[100000] you're creating a new object just like every other object, and it gets initialized, etc.

node.contents: The JLS provides all the specific info about this:

astNode.text: The JLS provides all the specific info about this:

node.contents: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se5.0/html/arrays.html

astNode.text: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se5.0/html/arrays.html

node.contents: So, no. You can't avoid "initializing" an array. That's just not how Java works. There's simply no such thing as uninitialized heap memory; many people call that a "feature" as it prevents you from accessing uninitialized memory.

astNode.text: So, no. You can't avoid "initializing" an array. That's just not how Java works. There's simply no such thing as uninitialized heap memory; many people call that a "feature" as it prevents you from accessing uninitialized memory.

node.contents: @EvgeniyDorofeev Louis has certainly no intention to dispute the well-known contents of the JLS. He said that the JVM doesn't need to physically initialize an array if it can prove this will not be observed by running code.

astNode.text: @EvgeniyDorofeev Louis has certainly no intention to dispute the well-known contents of the JLS. He said that the JVM doesn't need to physically initialize an array if it can prove this will not be observed by running code.

node.contents: Yup. The JLS specifies semantics, not implementation. If it can prove your code doesn't _care_ what the initial value will be, it could legally omit the initialization.

astNode.text: Yup. The JLS specifies semantics, not implementation. If it can prove your code doesn't _care_ what the initial value will be, it could legally omit the initialization.

node.contents: More precisely, it must prove that no uninitialized location can possibly be read.

astNode.text: More precisely, it must prove that no uninitialized location can possibly be read.

node.contents: Right, already looking into Unsafe, played with it before and know how to circumvent security. allocateMemory hardly can help it returns a reference to an area, but I want a regular int[] Object. Used to work with C and Assembler. C offers malloc and calloc. The former does no initialization and it makes sense. Just was wondering if there is anything like that in Java (deep inside).

astNode.text: Right, already looking into Unsafe, played with it before and know how to circumvent security. allocateMemory hardly can help it returns a reference to an area, but I want a regular int[] Object. Used to work with C and Assembler. C offers malloc and calloc. The former does no initialization and it makes sense. Just was wondering if there is anything like that in Java (deep inside).

node.contents: Just imagine, right now millions of JVMs are doing billions of useless array initializations (or inefficient string concatinations which could be improved by 30%) :)

astNode.text: Just imagine, right now millions of JVMs are doing billions of useless array initializations (or inefficient string concatinations which could be improved by 30%) :)

node.contents: There is a lot of useless initializaiton in Java; on the other hand, there are no buffer overrung attacks, no null pointer dereference attacks, etc. That's why people love it.

astNode.text: There is a lot of useless initializaiton in Java; on the other hand, there are no buffer overrung attacks, no null pointer dereference attacks, etc. That's why people love it.

node.contents: @EvgeniyDorofeev: If the JIT can prove it's safe, it probably omits the initialization. Don't make assumptions about how Java actually translates to CPU instructions.

astNode.text: @EvgeniyDorofeev: If the JIT can prove it's safe, it probably omits the initialization. Don't make assumptions about how Java actually translates to CPU instructions.

node.contents: @Louis I don't want to browse JLS to prove the opposite. But I am 100% certain that byte[] is ALWAYS intialized with false, byte[] - double[] with 0. Just like object arrays of any type are always initialized with null. Just like fields in any object are always initialized with default value: 0, false or null

astNode.text: @Louis I don't want to browse JLS to prove the opposite. But I am 100% certain that byte[] is ALWAYS intialized with false, byte[] - double[] with 0. Just like object arrays of any type are always initialized with null. Just like fields in any object are always initialized with default value: 0, false or null

node.contents: You are fighting at the wrong front here: low-level optimization of Java code is trusted upon the JIT compiler and giving this kind of degree of low-level control to Java code is, simply put, not idiomatic. String concatenation is quite a well-defined operation, making it an easy target for JIT optimization, if someone cares enough to do it.

astNode.text: You are fighting at the wrong front here: low-level optimization of Java code is trusted upon the JIT compiler and giving this kind of degree of low-level control to Java code is, simply put, not idiomatic. String concatenation is quite a well-defined operation, making it an easy target for JIT optimization, if someone cares enough to do it.

node.contents: But anyway, in OpenJDK you do have the option to allocate native memory with no initialization: sun.misc.Unsafe.allocateMemory. Obviously, this is not general Java API, but specific to one implementation.

astNode.text: But anyway, in OpenJDK you do have the option to allocate native memory with no initialization: sun.misc.Unsafe.allocateMemory. Obviously, this is not general Java API, but specific to one implementation.

node.contents: I've done some investigation. There is no legal way to create uninitialized array in Java. Even JNI NewXxxArray creates initialized arrays. So it is impossible to know exactly the cost of array zeroing. Nevertheless I've done some measurements:

astNode.text: I've done some investigation. There is no legal way to create uninitialized array in Java. Even JNI NewXxxArray creates initialized arrays. So it is impossible to know exactly the cost of array zeroing. Nevertheless I've done some measurements:

node.contents: 1) 1000 byte arrays creation with different array size

astNode.text: 1) 1000 byte arrays creation with different array size

elements.contents: long t0 = System.currentTimeMillis(); for(int i = 0; i < 1000; i++) { // byte[] a1 = new byte[1]; byte[] a1 = new byte[1000000]; } System.out.println(System.currentTimeMillis() - t0);

comments.text: // byte[] a1 = new byte[1]; byte[] a1 = new byte[1000000]; } System.out.println(System.currentTimeMillis() - t0);

node.contents: on my PC it gives < 1ms for byte[1] and ~500 ms for byte[1000000]. Sounds impressive to me.

astNode.text: on my PC it gives < 1ms for byte[1] and ~500 ms for byte[1000000]. Sounds impressive to me.

node.contents: 2) We don't have a fast (native) method in JDK for filling arrays, Arrays.fill is too slow, so let's see at least how much 1000 copying of 1,000,000 size array takes with native System.arraycopy

astNode.text: 2) We don't have a fast (native) method in JDK for filling arrays, Arrays.fill is too slow, so let's see at least how much 1000 copying of 1,000,000 size array takes with native System.arraycopy

elements.contents: byte[] a1 = new byte[1000000]; byte[] a2 = new byte[1000000]; for(int i = 0; i < 1000; i++) { System.arraycopy(a1, 0, a2, 0, 1000000); }

units.rawText: byte[] a1 = new byte[1000000]; byte[] a2 = new byte[1000000]; for(int i = 0; i < 1000; i++) { System.arraycopy(a1, 0, a2, 0, 1000000); }

node.contents: It is 700 ms.

astNode.text: It is 700 ms.

node.contents: It gives me reasons to believe that a) creating long arrays is expensive b) it seems to be expensive because of useless initialization.

astNode.text: It gives me reasons to believe that a) creating long arrays is expensive b) it seems to be expensive because of useless initialization.

node.contents: 3) Let's take sun.misc.Unsafe http://www.javasourcecode.org/html/open-source/jdk/jdk-6u23/sun/misc/Unsafe.html. It is protected from external usage but not too much

node.contents: 4) Unsafe has no direct methods to work with arrays. It needs to know class fields, but reflection shows no fields in an array. There is not much info about arrays internals, I guess it is JVM / platform specific. Nevertheless, it is, like any other Java Object, header + fields. On my PC/JVM it looks like

astNode.text: 4) Unsafe has no direct methods to work with arrays. It needs to know class fields, but reflection shows no fields in an array. There is not much info about arrays internals, I guess it is JVM / platform specific. Nevertheless, it is, like any other Java Object, header + fields. On my PC/JVM it looks like

node.contents: Now, using Unsafe, I will create byte[10], allocate a 10 byte memory buffer and use it as my array's elements:

node.contents: Conclusions

astNode.text: Conclusions

node.contents:
1. It seems that Java array creation is slow because of useless element zeroing.

  2. We cannot change it, but Oracle can. No need to change anything in JLS, just add native methods to java.lang.reflect.Array like

    public static native xxx[] newUninitialziedXxxArray(int size);

astNode.text:
1. It seems that Java array creation is slow because of useless element zeroing.

  2. We cannot change it, but Oracle can. No need to change anything in JLS, just add native methods to java.lang.reflect.Array like

    public static native xxx[] newUninitialziedXxxArray(int size);
